Foreign Office L Ko # T. 11024/11024/380 ^ehted 10th January, 1934 to India Office (with enclosure) Subject. Limit for Persian territorial Patera* CX. 11524/11524/380 if (*** H. W. 1. 10th January, 1934, , ^ Sir, /P'' 7 I am directed by Secretary Sur John Simon to request you to inform Secretary Sir Samuel Hoare that he has && had under / consideration a statement contained in paragraph 7 of Mr. Mallet’s telegram No. 26b of the Ibth October , a cJopy of which is enclosed, to the effect that the Persian Minister for For eign Affa^rs recently claimed a teii-mile limit for Persain terr itorial waters. 2. As Sir Samuel Hoare is aware, there is no international agreement laying down the limit of territorial waters for all countries. His Uajestyls Government in the United Kingdom claim three m iles only, but Persia is by no means alone in claiming more; indeed at the Grnference forthe Codification of International Law held at the Hague in 1930, while most of the i important maritime stat^ s claimed no more thf%/ three miles, t:.ey in a fliinority. At that Conference, it may be recalled, t e Persain representatives claimed a limit of six miles |Ubis plus an adjacent zone, the breadth of which does not appear to have been specified. Although the a ersAan representative did not himself give any explanation of the prupose for which this adjacent zone was claimed by his c vernment , the majority of other States which put forward a similar claim on this occasio* made it clear that they required the adjacent zone partly at least for purposes of customs control. The Under Secretary bf State, v India Office.ty :2s. The ten mile limit recently claimed by the Persian Minister for Foreign Affairs appears at first sight to be incompatible with the clainjmade in 1930 by the Persian representative at the Conference, but it may well be that Kazemi had in mind the adjacent zone when mentioning the higher figure. Whatever may be theprecise wxtent of the Persia- n claim , it is evident that if ti includes an adjacent zone it cannot be far short of the ten-mile limit. 4. In t he t bsence of any international agreement, it is, in Sir John Simon’s view, impossible to base a refusal to accept the Persian trovernmentfe claim to a ten-mile limit upon the international position • Not would it appear disirable to base such a refusal upon tfeefact that the Persian claim at the 1930 conference was not to a ten mile limit, since to do so **** would go near to bring an acceptance of the claim to a six mile limit and an adjacent zone, which would be contrarey to the g wx gpura general policy of His Maj estyle u overnment in t e United Kn 'ingdom on the subject, In these circumstances, it cannot be expected that the Persian drovernment will admit the justice c of any complaints regarding interference with shipping by the Persian coast, in cases where it would be a sound defence that the action was taken within the limits of Persian territor- i<'tl waters • It appears therefoe to Sie John tiimon that , while peotests should in such cases continue to be made in order to safeguard trie principle of a three mile limit, His Majesty’s Government ha¥e no means of enforcing their view.» FflRgpBPiSy ■' ■ Pf s \ ;[ % — • > 3 : • 5* Subject to the concurrence of Sir Samuel Hoare Sir John Simon proposes to inform His Majesty’s Minister at xehran ofthe position as set forth above for his guidance § and he suggests that it may be desirable that the Political J*«xi Resident in the Peri^n sulf should take steps to warn the masters of vesnels from the Arab states ofthe Persian Gulf in sx* suitable terms of the practical effects of the Persian xHx claim to ten-mile limit of territorial waters* 6. ^similar letter is beir« sent to th©Admiralty* I am, Gir, Your obedient^ervant* Sd. (7) Minister for Foreign Affairs said I should get answers about all dhow questions soon but did we not realise that Persia claimed ten mile limit for territorial waters.? I replied that he must know quite well that we should never xjlxj admit this. mmmm1* The Political Agent, Muscat. 2. The Political Agent, Bahrain. / J 3. A copy of this letter is being sen/ to the Admiralty, Your obedient servant. !/• T .C. '^Iton.Copy. HO. 102(4/10/37) BritisJi Legation, TEHRAN. 17th November, 1937. Sir, /ith reference to my despatch No.28 of the 5th April, I transmit to you herewith a copy of a despatch from the Foreign Office regarding the attitude to be adopted by His Majesty’s Government in the event of the arrest of a British subject at the outer anchorage at Bushire. 2. Subject to any observations which you may wish to offer, particularly with regard to the proposed definition of the outer anchorage, 1 would propose to reply that I agree that the best course, in the particular circumstances existing at Bushire, is that suggested in paragraphs 3 and 4 of the Foreign Office despatch, and that I also agree that no communication need be made to the Iranian Government until a concrete case arises. It is undesirable to enter upon a barren controversy with the Iranian Government over this question, and I consider that this will be best achieved by adopting the course proposed in paragraphs 3 to 5 of the Foreign Office despatch. I would suggest that it should be understood that if a case arises involving Iranian juris diction over a British subject on a ship at the outer anchorage, His Majesty's Legation should at once be informed by telegraph, so that the necessary communication can be made to the Iranian Government without delay. It does not seem necessary that a similar communication should be made simultaneously to the Governor of Bushire. ^• Before replying to the Foreign Office on these lines, I should be glad to learn whether you wish to offer any further observations in the light of the despatch of which a copy is enclosed. 4 / O.K.Caroe Esquire, C.I.E., # ' The Acting Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire.3./ IS Copy. No.389 (E 5852/653/34). FOREIGN OFFICE,S.W.l. 18tn October, 1937. 3ir, I have had under cone ideration your despatch Ho. 128 (4/5/37) of the 5th April regarding the arrest by the Hersian authorities of a member of the crew of tne German 3.3.Geierfels after being involved in an affray with Persian coolies on board that vessel while it was lying at tne outer anchorage at Bushire, and in which you requested instructions regarding the attitude which His Majesty's Government proposed to adopt in the event of a British subject being arrested by the Persian authorities in corresponding circumstances. 2. After carefully weighing the various considerations put forward in your despatch under reference, I am of tne opinion that for practical reasons it is desirable that Persian juris diction should be recognised over tne outer anchorage of the Persian port of Bushire. Owing to tne snallowness or tne harbour, this is a place where sea-going vessels perform the operations which they would normally perform inside a port, and in so far as foreign vessels g 0 there for the purpose of establishing contact with the shore, and to tnat end admit Persian officials on board, they must be assumed to accept some measure of Persian jurisdiction. At the same time, it seems desirable to find a way of meeting tne practical needs of this situation which does not prejudice tne position wnicn nis 'fejesty's Government have ta*en up with regard to tne limits of territorial waters and, in particular, does not imply any recognition by His Majesty's Government of tne Persian claim to a s ix-mile limit (or in exceptional circumstances twelve miles) or a contiguous zone.3 — 2 - In these circumstancesi I consider that the difficulty could best be met, if Hia ^Jesty’s aorernment were to take the line tnat, in view of the special circumatancee obtaining at Buahire, they intend, ao far as they are concerned, to regard the outer anchorage as being under Persian jurisdiction in the same manner as if the anchorage were part of the Persian port of Bushire, and that snips going there will accordingly be deemed to be in the same position as if they were in Persian national waters. This method appears prefer able to one involving any attempt to negotiate a special agreement with the Persian Government in regard to the outer ancho^rage at Bushire, more especially as that Government clearly could not be expected to accept a proposal for sucn an agreement, the conclusion of which would be completely inconsistent with the attitude which they have always main tained regarding the limits of Persian territorial waters. 4. If this policy is to serve its purpose, it ought to be communicated officially to the Persian Government. The communication would be a statement of the view which Hia JlaJ esty* s Government had decided unilaterally to adopt with regard to this matter, and would contain a definition of what they conceived to be the geographical limits of tne anchorage. I am advised that a simple definition wnicn would be adequate for this purpose would be 'an area within one mile of tne chartered position of tne Guter Anchorage light buoy'. 1 shall be glad if you will consider this suggestion, if necessary in consultation with tne acting Political Resident in tne Persian Gulf, and furnish me with your opinion on it in due course. 5. A further point requiring consideration is that of the t irae /3- time at wiiicti the proposed coimnunication which is to be addressed to the Persian Government should be made in order best to serve the purpose in view. In general, I consider that little would be gained by making this communication before the particular circumstances which would render it necessary nave arisen, and it might b© best to wait until a concrete case of the kind contemplated in tne last sentence of paragraph 2 of your despatch under reference has occurred. Nevertheless, I am prepared to leave it entirely to your discretion to decide cn the time and manner of making such a communication, and you are authorised to take such action at any time when, in the light of local considerations, it may appear desirable. I am, with great truth and regard, Sir, Your obedient servant, (for tne Secretary of StateJ sd. G.'Y.Hendel.CONFIDENTIAL. No. C/540 of 1942. / mu M.sMy. C/539 of 7th May 1942*Telegram S* From Political Resident, at Bahrain. To H.M. Minister, Tehran No. T/220 Dated 7th April 1942. Reoorts sliow that arms traffic (cf. my telegram No. T/163*March 26th not repeated to Senior Naval Officer) and slave trade in Gulf are being carried on almost exclusively in Persian dhows. I presume there is no objection in present circumstances to such dhows being searched by His Majesty f s ships even inside Persian territorial waters. Please confirm. RESIDENT - Telegram S. From H.M. Fact that we have either sumk or appropriated Persian Navy maka^ action by us ?not unreasonable. - BULIAKD - Telegram R. From India Office, London. To H.M. Minister, Tehran. I am providing all ships with a precis of enclosure to your letter with instructions to search as many dhows as possible in that area provided that it does not interfere with the efficiency of the scout patrols. /4- 4 f> ~2— - Senior Naval Officer - No.428-S. Office of the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire, the 22nd May, 1942. Copy forwarded to - The Secretary to the Government of India, External Affairs Department, New Delhi, His Majesty*s Minister, Tehran, K 0 . 29 -B, The Political Agent, Kuwait, The Political Agent, Bahrain, The Political Agent, Muscat, with reference to Residency Printed Letter No.C/539, dated the 7th May 1942. / y> 'sr ' V 1 KCONFWFNTIA 1 Kuwait No gif Dated )y British Legation, T2HEO. 19th May, 1942. To Gons ul-General, BUS HI KB. Malays0/42 of the 19th May 1942. Sir, Z 5 Hth reference to ay telegram Ho. 75 to Bahrain dated the 13th April, regarding the use of H.M. ships in the suppression of the Gulf arms traffic, I have the honour to transmit to you herewith a copy of a memorandum from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs reouesting that H.M. ships should lend their assistance to the Persian authorities in case of need. A copy of my reply is also enclosed. I should he glad if you would help the Persian authorities as far as you reasonably can in their efforts to prevent this traffic. I note from your despatch No.404 of the 25th March to the Political Resident Persian Gulf, that your fbree is being strengthened and that this is expected to deter the smugglers. I have the honour to be, Sir, Tour obedient servant, Sgd. R.W.Bullard. To The Senior Naval Officer, PERSIAN GULF. No.533-S. With reference to ny telegram h'o#75 to Bahrain, dated the 13th April, regarding the use of H.M.ships in the suppression of the Gulf arms traffic, I have the honour to transmit to you here with a copy of a memorandum from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs requeslinfe that H#M-ships should lend their assistance to the Persian authorities in case of need# A copy of my reply is also enclosed# 2# I should be glad if you would help the Persian authorities as far as you reasonably can in their efforts to prevent this traffic# I note from your despatch ^o#404 of the 25th M^rch to the Political Resident Persian Gulf that your force is being strength ened and that this is expected to deter the smugglers# 3# Copies of this despatch are being sent to His Majesty’s Prin cipal Secretary for Foreign Affairs and to the Senior aval Officer Persian Gulf (?). The Senior Eaval Officer, Persian Gulf# Translation of note from Iranian Ministry of Affairs to His Majesty’s Legation, Tehran, Ko.339 of 1942. Foreign 28 th *ipril Memorandum# the M#F.A.present their complimetots to J#M.legation and have the honour to state that, according to a report received, in the neighbourhood of Gangan, Aslavieh and Taheri ports, etc.brigands constantly and unscrupulously import arms by way of the sea and d± distribute and sell them amnng the Arabs through their agents and their own companions. Under the present world conditions and relations existing between the Imperial Government and H.M# Government, which necessitate co-operation in the prevention of such activities, since it will not be possible to prevent smuggl ing of arms with such amnieh forces as is stationed on the coast without the help of a naval force, it is requested that arrange ments may be made temporarily in this time of war for the British Forces to lend their assistance to the appropriate authorities of the Imperial Government on their request and in case of need in the prevention of arms smuggling, and that the I • ■ 1 #A# may be informed of the result. * nr ti a Seal of th e M.F.A. Copy was also sent to S.N. 0 ##PG. _ (No.6 (124/30/42) of l9.5.42)of letter and its enclosures/. Memorandum Ho#30Q from H.ii. Legation, Tehran, to Iranian M.F.A., dated 19th May 1942. His Majesty’s Legation present their compliments to the Imperial Ministry of Foreign affairs and with reference to the / Ministry’s — — 11No* 381• Your Excellency, ML T - 2 - Ministry»e memorandum No.339 of the 8th Ordibehesht (28th April) regarding the smuggling of arms by sea, have the honour to state that the matter has been brought to the notice of the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf, who has been requested to give all possible assistance. 2. The British -authorities in the Persian Gulf are already co operating to the best of their ability in the suppression of this traffic, and as a result of their vigilance 42 rifles, a pistol, and a quantity of ammunition were seized from four dhows at Dubai on the 13th March; four fifles were also seized from a boom at Kuwait on the 8th March. Seal of H.M,Legation. Office of the Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf, 11th June, 1942. In reply to your No.6 (124/30/42) dated 19th May, 1942, and enclosures, I have the honour to inform you that my ships have orders to search dhows for slaves and arms whenever tiiis can be done without detriment to their duties in connection with the war. 2. The gun-running is more difficult to deal with as it takes place in a less frequented part cf the Gulf than the other. Actually I have a ship visiting Tahiri tomorrow, 12th June, but as she hae to collect distressed airmen who have been well looked alter there, I have had to tell her not to seach dhows on this occasion. to tpare ships for searching dhows but I will continue to keep the matter in mind tion you can give me as to the most and gun-running is suspected. and will be glad of any informa- likely localities where slavery -His Britannic Majesty’s Minister, The British Legation, Tehran. location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 26; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 3-24; these numbers are written in pencil, and are not circled. A previous foliation sequence between ff 22-24, which was written in pencil and not circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: This file concerns a recent claim, made by the Persian Minister for Foreign Affairs to HM Chargé d’Affaires to Persia [temporarily held by Victor Alexander Louis Mallet], to a ten mile limit for Persian territorial waters. It contains copies of correspondence between the Foreign Office, the India Office, and the Admiralty, regarding whether or not Britain should give a formal response to what is referred to as being an informal claim made by the Persian Minister for Foreign Affairs. The issue is discussed with reference to recent incidents involving Arab dhows in the Gulf.James Sidney Barnes, writing on behalf of the Lord Commissioners of the Admiralty [as Principal Assistant Secretary], advises that there should be no formal repudiation and that British officials should avoid any action that might in any way compromise the views of His Majesty's Government on territorial waters.In addition, the file includes a copy of instructions, produced by the Foreign Office and relayed by the British Legation, Tehran, regarding the attitude that should be taken in the event of the arrest of a British subject by the Persian authorities at the outer anchorage at Bushire.The file concludes with copies of correspondence regarding instructions for searching Persian dhows that are suspected of arms trafficking. Other correspondents in the file include the British Minister, Tehran, and the Senior Naval Officer, Persian Gulf.

name.namePart: Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf
